Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Deformation Mechanisms in Austenitic Iron-Manganese Steels with Changes in Stacking Fault Energy, Strain Rate and Tempeature
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
To understand the complex deformation mechanisms exhibited by austenitic iron-manganese steels, which include transformation-induced plasticity (TRIP), twinning-induced plasticity (TWIP), and dislocation glide, requires systematic mechanical testing with materials characterization down to the atomic scale. Changes in stacking-fault energy (SFE) with composition and temperature strongly influence the active deformation mechanism. Although the determination of SFE is challenging and most investigations rely on calculated values, careful experimental methods using weak-beam dark field (WBDF) imaging of partial dislocation separation can provide accurate SFE measurements. In addition to the composition and deformation temperature, important microstructural and processing parameters include grain size and strain rate. Correlation of the SFE with the mechanical behavior is a critical aspect for developing a basic understanding of the structure-property-processing relationships that will allow for future advances in the design of new high-manganese austenitic steels.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
In the last five years, there has been a significant increase in the research activity associated with high-manganese austenitic steels as evidenced by both the number of scientific publications and patent applications. These steels are excellent candidates for applications requiring high formability and energy absorption such as cold-stamping of automotive parts owing to their exceptional ductility, strain-hardening, and toughness. This proposal describes collaboration between Vanderbilt University, the Ohio State University, the RWTH University and the Max-Planck-Institut f√ºr Eisenforschung in Germany, and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory to address the basic science involved with the future development of high-manganese austenitic steels. This international collaboration not only allows the combined expertise of the individual investigators to be focused on understanding the complex deformation mechanisms in these alloys, but it will also promote the education of graduate students who will benefit from the international experience. Student education and training will be enhanced through international collaborations. Educational opportunities enabled by these activities will be made available to under-represented groups through the Vanderbilt-Fisk Bridge program.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of next generation steels has gained interest from around the world. This research utilizes collaboration between the U.S.A. and Germany (Vanderbilt University, the Max Planck Institute for Iron Research, The Ohio State University, Colorado School of Mines and the National Institute of Standards and Technology) to effectively design, process and deform both model and industrially relevant alloys. Atomic-resolution characterization of the deformation-induced defects involves collaboration with the Center for Electron Microscopy and Analysis, the Ernst Ruska Center, the Molecular Foundry at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and Oak Ridge National Lab. Next generation steel research is geared towards understanding the stability of single-phase austenitic steels to provide a better understanding of the mechanical properties in more industrial and economical multi-phase ferritic-martensitic-austenitic steels. This project also provided the resources and opportunities for a student, Jake Benzing, to complete his Ph.D. at Vanderbilt University with a dissertation title: The Influences of Strain Rate on Mechanical Properties and Deformation Mechanisms of High-Mn and Medium-Mn TWIP-TRIP Steels.

 

Within the past few decades, advanced high strength steels (AHSS) have been incorporated into automotive vehicles to reduce their weight and improve the strength of structural components. More stringent fuel economy standards and crash safety tests continue to drive the implementation and evolution of AHSS. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration requires a fleet wide fuel economy average of 54.5 mpg by 2025, (including passenger cars and light trucks). The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety continues to develop more rigorous new crash safety tests, such as the small overlap frontal crash test implemented in 2012. The new small overlap frontal crash test raises challenging alloy design issues that may be resolved in part with new generations of AHSS. In comparison to lighter-weight materials, (such as aluminum and magnesium alloys that reduce total vehicle weight), AHSS offer a significant improvement in crash safety and production cost, meaning AHSS are the favored material of choice for automotive light weighting.

 

The design, testing and qualification of second and third generation AHSS have progressed rapidly and will ultimately provide critical solutions for improved crash performance and weight reduction of automotive vehicles in the near future. The combination of both high strength and high ductility is a characteristic feature in second and third generation AHSS and depends on microstructures that are engineered to contain a specific phase of iron (austenite). The deformation behavior and thus mechanical properties of austenite can be tuned through careful alloying and thermo-mechanical processing. High-Mn and medium-Mn twinning-induced and transformation-induced plasticity (TWIP/TRIP) steels have garnered significant attention because the tunable deformation mechanisms in the austenite provide excellent combinations of strength and ductility. However, there are still many aspects of the processing-structure-property relationships in these steels that are not well understood. More specifically, a fundamental understanding of the deformation mechanisms of TWIP-TRIP steels at high strain rates (experienced during crashes and advanced forming processes) will be beneficial for implementing these steels into automotive vehicles and designing future generations of AHSS. Under crash conditions, steel components are subjected to a wide range of strain rates, most of which can be simulated with tensile tests in the strain rate range from 10-2/s to 103/s. As such, the structure-property information from high strain rate tensile testing is potentially useful for alloy design and crystal plasticity models to predict the performance of sheet steel forming behavior and automotive crash response of components in the vehicle body.

 

Outcomes from this project on a Fe-25Mn-3Al-3Si TWIP-TRIP steel and a Fe-12Mn-3Al-0.05C TWIP-TRIP steel show that both steels become stronger at higher strain rates. Also, both steels maintain moderate amounts of ductility as compared to quasi-static strain rates and therefore the product of strength and elongation increases as strain rate increases. These excellent trends in mechanical properties are a direct result of careful design, alloying and thermo-mechanical processing. This research benefits industrial automotive research in the areas of vehicle light weighting and crash safety performance. Medium-Mn steels provide an area of opportunity for AHSS research since the balance in composition and simple processing techniques provide an optimum balance in cost and desired mechanical properties. As tailpipe emissions decrease to meet federal regulations, production emissions become more significant to the total carbon foot print of a vehicle’s life cycle.Since the automotive industry is already built around the production of conventional steels, implementation of advanced high strength steel into a next generation car body is the most sustainable approach (from economic and environmental standpoints) as compared to replacing all steel with aluminum or magnesium alloys. Even for future fleets of all electric vehicles, AHSS could still be the most sustainable material of choice.

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2018
Modified by: James E Wittig

Next generation steel research is geared towards understanding the stability of single-phase austenitic steels to provide a better understanding of the mechanical properties in more industrial and economical multi-phase ferritic-martensitic-austenitic steels.
